ContentStructure.title: It is said that Anthropometry originated in the 13th century and guess who was responsible for its origin?    It was Marco Polo! He described the different human body builds and sizes.    You know why it’s important?   Because Interior designers need to make sure that the products they design are the right size for the user and therefore comfortable to use.

A tool for interior designers can be extremely helpful when designing joinery or cabinetry, furniture, planning circulation spaces, work spaces, accessible spaces and to generally make the user comfortable in their interior environment.   The measurements shown are in millimeters.
The image shows the average height and width of a human being.   This measurement is useful while designing joinery or space planning.
The image shows the maximum width of a human being when the arms are stretched.   This is useful while designing a small bathroom.
The image shows the measurement related to the sitting position or climbing position.   This helps in designing chairs or stairs.
The image shows the measurements related to reach of forward outstretched arms.   Reference to this is important while designing cupboards and shelves over benches and to windows behind furniture.
The image shows the maximum reach (flat footed) straight up. This can be referred to for the maximum height of close shelves or cupboards while also considering the angle.
The image shows the height of the forearm when standing and bent at right angles. This is useful for determining the heights of work surfaces.
The image shows the height of a person when kneeling or crouching down.   You can determine minimum heights of shelving or basic reach.
The image shows the height of a medium use workbench.   It also shows space allocated for the front of the foot to fit under the bench.
Height of a Medium Use Workbench
The image shows a person sitting at a table. The height of the chair and table are shown in relation to the body.
The image shows heights and widths of shelves showing the reach required and also the eye line.

The image shows a person in sitting position showing the base of the bent forearm to the seat height for armrests, the thickness of the thigh and the height from the base of the thigh to the floor for clearance under tables.
The image shows the eyes height in relation to the floor. Use this to determine placing of items such as switching or signage.
Eyes Height in Relation to the Floor
The image shows the length of the legs and body combined when sitting on the floor or bed. Use this to help determine leg room.
Length of the Legs and Body Combined
The various types of anthropometric data available for an interior designer are:

The first type is the Structural anthropometric data which are measurements of the bodily dimensions of subjects in a fixed (static) position.  Some examples of the use of structural anthropometric data are to specify furniture dimensions and ranges of adjustment and to determine ranges of clothing sizes.
This image shows the measurements of the overall human body.
This image shows the human body measurements while performing certain actions or movements.
The second type is the Functional Anthropometric Data. They are used to describe the movement of a body part with respect to a fixed reference point.

Example, data are available concerning the maximum forward reach of standing subjects. Functional anthropometric data are useful for designing workspaces and positioning objects within them, particularly in the design of aircraft cockpits, crane cabs, vehicle interiors and complex control panels in the process industries.
The third type is the Newtonian Anthropometric data. This is used in mechanical analysis of human body in action. It is used to compare loads on spine.
The clearance dimensions should be designed for the large, 95th percentile individual such as a male.
Intro to Principles in Application of Anthropometric Data

As an interior designer, it is necessary that you design the space in a manner that it will fit one and all. Your motto should be to let the small person reach and also let the large person fit.  You must ensure that the anthropometry should help you achieve the following:
Reach distances should be designed for the small,  5th percentile individual such as a female.
Average cannot be used - does not describe the ranges of different body dimensions.
General Approach to Using Anthropometric Data
The general approach in using anthropometric data is to determine the following:
Determine body dimensions important in the design
Define Population (e.g. adult - male; adult - female, children)
Principles in the Application of Anthropometric Data
There are several principles that as an interior designer you can apply to design a space.
The design should attempt to accommodate all (or nearly all) of the population.
Design for the maximum - if the maximum value accommodates all
Design for the minimum - if the minimum value determines that all are accommodated
Design for the maximum - if maximum value accommodates all.
A door lock must be no higher than the maximum vertical reach of a small person.
Design for the maximum - if maximum value accommodates all.
Seat heights and depths must not exceed the maximum height and buttock-knee lengths of small users.
Design for the minimum - if minimum value determines that all are accommodated.
A door handle must not be lower than the highest standing knuckle height in a population so that all users can open the door without stooping.
Design for the minimum - if minimum value determines that all are accommodated.
The width of a chair must be no narrower than the hip breadth of a large woman.
Design for the minimum - if minimum value determines that all are accommodated.
The height of a doorway must be no lower than the stature of a tall man (plus an allowance for clothing and shoes).
You must design to accommodate all.
This method of design is a preferred  method, but it is not always possible.
A person may be average on one or two body dimensions but it is impossible to find anyone who  is average in many dimensions.
Intro to Principles in Application of Anthropometric Data
There are times when the average may be acceptable. Examples: counter height at grocery store.
Fill in the blank with the correct answer and click Submit. The term that relates human body measurements and its relations with the space around it is called anthropometrics .
Incorrect - The answer is anthropometrics. Click Next to continue.
You must answer the question before continuing.

ContentStructure.title: Veena had to design the cabinets for Anupama’s kitchen. She was also given the project of designing a home office in one of the bedrooms for Rajesh.    Anupama is a petite person, and loves to bake. Rajesh is tall and needs to sit at the computer for long hours. Veena took the height of both Anupama and Rajesh before beginning to plan the cabinets and work stations.
It is important to have Rajesh’s sitting position measured to decide on the height of the chair and table in relation to his body.  Choose the correct answer and click Submit.
Incorrect - Yes, Rajesh’s sitting position should be measured. Click Next to continue.
You must answer the question before continuing.

ContentStructure.title: In this lesson, you have learned that:  Design essentially involves an activity that translates an idea into a blueprint.   A group of activities that change a space into an effective living area is termed as Interior design.  An interior designer is professionally trained to create a functional and quality interior environment.  Interior designing is a career which requires lot of creative skills in the area of art and design.  Anthropometry is a word which has a Greek origin, where the word ‘anthors’ means man and ‘metre’ means to measure. Here, the size and proportions of human body are measured and compared.  The various types of anthropometric data available for an interior designer are:   Structural anthropometric data Functional anthropometric data  Newtonian anthropometric data
